input_full.title: Create "loop opportunities" document cataloging tool-agent interaction patterns
input_full.body:
Catalogue all the ways custom tools (MCP, CLI, skills) plus Claude Code could potentially interact -- both exclusively within the dev tooling sense (e.g., archive -> oracle -> self-improve feedback loops) and when interacting with the app/tool being developed.

In a brand new SBS repo there wouldn't be any app-specific interactions yet, so the document should be framework-general where possible and SBS-specific where we have concrete examples.

**Scope includes:**
- Dev tool <-> dev tool loops (e.g., archive feeds oracle feeds self-improve)
- Dev tool <-> Claude Code native capabilities (e.g., MCP tools + Task agents + TodoWrite)
- Dev tool <-> application under development (e.g., Lean LSP tools used on the Lean code being built)
- Claude Code native <-> application (e.g., Bash/Read/Edit on app files, test runners)
- Compound loops spanning all three layers

---
Created with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

thinking_blocks.content:
The user wants to log an issue about creating a "loop opportunities" document that catalogs all the ways custom tools + Claude Code could interact, both within the dev tool sense and when interacting with the app/tool being developed.

Let me parse this:

- **Type:** This is about creating a new document - matches "housekeeping:docs" (document, docs)
- **Area:** This spans devtools broadly - could be area:devtools:skills, area:devtools:mcp, area:devtools:cli... it's really about the overall tooling interaction model
- **Title:** Something like "Create 'loop opportunities' document cataloging tool interaction patterns"
- **Body:** The description about cataloging all ways custom tools + Claude Code interact


- **Labels:** I'm leaning toward idea:exploration since this is about exploring interaction possibilities rather than documenting existing patterns, plus impact:dx since it directly affects developer experience. The area labels should include both area:devtools:skills and area:devtools:mcp since those are the main interaction points being explored.
